Derrick laughed. "I don't think I'm one ton. I'm big and I know it. But I don't care how many pounds I am. There's nobody out here to call me out of being a fatass."

"Except for me, fatass." said William. This earned a quick jab in the belly from Derrick.

"Have you looked in the mirror lately, big guy? I've noticed How much you've been swelling up, and I've been meaning to talk to you about that. I know it's freeing to be out here and eating whatever you want. But if you keep it up, you'll be a tubby fox too big to move, and I don't think I'll be able to help you then. And consider how easily you got fatigued today..."

"Yeah, yeah, I know. I'll cut down, I promise." said William. "Look, I know that you said it's dangerous to camp out here, but I'm still exhausted. I don't think I'll be able to make it back. Could we please camp out here?"
112132122.title: "Local herbs, and how to mix them into heal...

choices: Something invades their camp that night
1121321221.content:
Derrick sighed. "Well, if you're sure that you can't go on, then we'll camp out here. I don't want to, but I also don't want to have to drag you back. You rest here. We'll need a fire in order to keep any creatures around away from us tonight. I'll grab some firewood and maybe something to eat also." The deer rolled himself into his large belly and pushed himself up, brushing dirt and grass off of his belly and rump.

"Thanks, Derrick." said William, still too tired to move.

"Don't mention it," replied Derrick. The obese deer trudged off into the treeline as William was overcome by sleep.

***

Two hours later, William awoke. Dusk was already approaching and Derrick had built a fire near where the fox was resting. He was sitting next to the flames, eating from a giant mound of berries that lay beside him. The fox dragged himself over to the fire to join Derrick.

"Sleep well?" asked Derrick. He popped another handful of berries into his mouth.

"Yeah. I'm still exhausted, but now I don't feel like I'm about to pass out."

"That's good," muttered Derrick with a mouthful of the fruit in his mouth. "I got you something to eat." He reached forward and grabbed a stick from the fire. On the end of it was a roasting gourd-like vegetable. It was as big as a pumpkin and it was bright red. Derrick pointed it towards William. "Take it. It's only been cooking for a few minutes, so it shouldn't be that hot."

The fox pulled the vegetable off the stick. Derrick was right; it was warm but not too hot to handle. William took a hearty bite into it. It tastes exactly like a freshly baked cheery pie. "Wow, this is amazing!" said William, his muzzle covered in red juice.

"I figured you'd like it." said Derrick, smirking. The two ate in silence. William devoured the vegetable while Derrick demolished the pile of berries he gathered. Soon enough, William has consumed the entire thing. His gut was taunt, but he wasn't uncomfortably stuffed. Lazily rubbing a paw on his gut, he wiped away the red juice from his mouth, licking off his fingers. When Derrick swallowed the last of what had to be of the hundreds of berries, he let out a low, rumbling blech.

"Oof, maybe dessert was a bad idea..." moaned Derrick.

"Dessert? That was dessert for you? When did you have dinner?" asked William.

"When you were still napping. I got two of those things, one for me and one for you. I finished mine just before you woke up. But now I'm wishing I stopped there..." The deer gently rubbed his visibly swollen gut with paws and he laid down on his back, the mass of cream colored fur making up his overstuffed gut sticking out several feet all around him. William could see that the deer's belly was far to large for him to rub the entire globe that was his gut.

"Here, let me help..." William scooted over to Derrick and sat himself down on the deer's plump thighs, Derrick's ballooned belly in front of him.

"What are you doing..." moaned Derrick. But the moans of pain turned into moans of pleasure as his fox companion began rubbing his belly for him. The fox's paws made slow, gentle circles all over the deer's expanded gut, then long and deep caresses along the deer's flanks. William leaned forward to make sure he was also soothing the top of the deer's belly, the fox's own doughy belly pressing into Derrick.

Derrick quietly accepted the gut rub from William, letting out a series of burps each time the fox pressed deeply into his stomach. The deer particularly enjoyed the sensation of the fox's guy pressed against his, and he moaned to himself when he felt it.

After what felt like an eternity for Derrick, William said "That's for letting us stay here."

"No problem," the deer said, a silly smile was on his face. "Remind me to do what you say more often if it means I get more belly rubs." The deer yawned, closed his eyes, and in a moment was fast asleep.

William got off of the lap of his companion, rest his head against the deer's gut, and drifted off to sleep to the sounds of Derrick's meal digesting
1121321221.title: Derrick allows them to stay

1122.content:
William decides against collecting any of those items. Sure, there might be something there to help him on his journey. But he didn't want to run the risk of becoming a syrup-filled fox-balloon.

But as he tried to sneak away, William tripped over an exposed tree branch and felt to the forest floor with a loud thud. This got the attention of the syrup vines and they rushed over to where the noise came from. William quickly got to his feet and ran. Although the vines were fairly quick, he was just a bit faster and managed to get a good distance from them. But he knew that he couldn't just keep running from the vines and needed to hide. He quickly surveyed his surroundings. To his left was a large boulder, easily big enough for him to hide behind. To his right was a pathway leading to a cave inside of a hill. And further off in front of him was a large tree that he was certain he could climb up high on.

Where does William decide to hide?
1122.title: Move on. It's not worth it.

11222.content:
He took and sharp left and dove behind the boulder. Lying motionlessly and without making a sound, William waited. After a few moments, he heard the rustling of the vines skitter past. None of them got close to the boulder, and William heard them march off into the distance.

Waiting a few minutes to make sure he was safe, William got up and dusted himself off. He noted his luck finding such a large rock to shelter him. Or was it a rock? Now that he wasn't being pursued by creatures wanted to pump him full of sweet sap, William had a moment to look at this thing. It wasn't grey like most rocks but dark brown, almost like chocolate. And it's surface wasn't rough but rather covered in fur. He gently placed in hand on the mound and was shocked to discover that his hand was able to sink into the softness. He gave it a quick jab and the whole mound wobble uncontrollably for a few moments. Just then, William heard a loud muffled sound coming from the opposite side of the mound. Cautiously, he walked around the spheroid and, when he saw what was making that noise, he knew it wasn't a boulder after all.

Attached to the soft, furry mound was the head of a dog. But the poor thing's cheeks were so puffed up that it couldn't move its muzzle to speak but rather could only make muffled grunts and whimpers. The dog's neck was a thick ring of fat making it impossible for him to move his head around. William surmised that this guy somehow got so massively big that his girth swallowed up his limps and reduced him to a massive, immobile pup.

The dog made eye-contact with William and gave off a soft whimper.

"Hey, are you okay?" asked William. Another whimper. "Okay, I'll try to help you out. Is there anything you think I can do to help?"

The dog's eyes shot off into the distance. William turned around and saw lying on the ground a dozen feet away was a large jeweled belt. He walked over the picked it up off the ground. The belt itself was at least three inches thick and made of black leather. It was encrusted with numerous jewels and gems along the strap itself. The buckle was a round, gold plate with even more gems on it in many intricate patterns.

He walked back over to the massive mutt. "Is this what made you so huge?" asked William. The hound whimpered again in response.

William knew he wasn't going to get a clear answer from this guy about how to help with the present situation. So what does William do with the belt?
11222.title: Hide behind the boulder

112222.content:
William placed the belt on the forest floor. He drew his rusty sword and bashed its handle against the buckle of the belt. After several strong strikes, the plate on the buckle shattered. And when it did, the rest of the belt dissolved into a cloud of fine particles.

When the belt was destroyed, William turned around to see the body of the rotund hound begin to deflate rapidly and, after a few minutes, he could see the dog's limbs reemerge from the retreating mound of fat. Eventually, he had deflated enough to pick himself off of the ground and he brushed his coat of fur off as the last of the magic wore off.

"Man, I am so glad to be moving around again!" said the dog as he stretched out his arms and legs. In his now-deflated and no longer immobile form, William saw that he stood well over a foot taller than himself and was quite a handsome hound. What was most shocking to William was the dog's body. Rather than being a giant mound of soft pudge, the hound was very muscular with large, defined biceps and pecs, bulky thighs, and a plump yet firm rump.

William was shocked by this transformation. "So, are you fine now?" is all that he could bring himself to ask.

"Yep! Back to normal! And thanks to you!" The hound walked over to William and embraced him in a tight hug. "I had been stuck like that for the past several days. I tired to get some other strangers to help, but all they did was take my things and leave me."

"It's...no problem." gasped William since the hound was squeezing his body in his strong arms. "Can you please...let me down now?"

"Opps! Sorry!" He let William down and stuck out his paw. "I'm Tucker, by the way!"

William shook his paw. "And I'm William. So did that belt thing turn you into..."

"A giant fat ass of a dog? Yeah." replied Tucker. "I guess it serves me right. I found that belt and knew that it had some magical properties. I should have been more careful when trying it out rather than just using it out in the middle of the woods where nobody was around."

"Ah, well, don't beat yourself too much over it," said William. "But now that you're better, I ought to be..."

"Wait!" said Tucker. "You really helped me out there. There has to be some kind of reward I can give you!"

"Don't worry about. It was the least I co-"

"No, I insist!" said Tucker.

Does William take Tucker's reward?
112222.title: Smash it to pieces

1122221.content:
William is now an adventurer. Adventurers, by their nature, are rewarded from completing their quests. And that is just want William has done. He has completed a quest in a way. Sure, he wasn't tasked with finding a blimped-up hound and breaking his curse. But this nevertheless was like a quest. So although William had initially turned down the reward, he figured that this was just the start of his adventuring career and he couldn't start it by turning down just rewards.

"Alright, fine." said William. "What's this reward?"

"Well..." Tucker began. "I don't have anything on me right now. When I was in my previous round hound state, I couldn't stop all those thieves from taking everything I carried with me. But look here. I don't live too far away. I'm live in a cabin on the eastern edge of these woods. Providing that nothing bugs us along the way, we could make it there in a few hours. And I have a ton of treasures there from my past adventures."

William was mildly annoyed with this. He was hoping to explore the forest for longer, and following Tucker back to his place would only set back his plans. But the dog was insistent on giving him a reward, so there was no point in further arguments.

"Okay, lead the way."

For the next four hours, Tucker lead William through the woods. During the trip, Tucker recanted William with stories of his many past adventures. And during the trip, William was able to sneak a few quick glances at Tucker's plump rump as it wobbled at they walked. Tucker caught him staring a few times but didn't say anything out loud.

Evening approached on the land, and the duo reached a log cabin. "Ah, home sweet home!" said Tucker. He walked up to the door of the cabin and lifted up a rock on the ground beside it. Under the rock was a brass key that Tucker placed in the keyhole and unlocked the door. Tucker rushed into the building and lit a few lanterns. William saw that the cabin's interior was a large room, with a massive bed at the far end and a night stand. On the walls flanking the bed were shelves filled with an assortment of trinkets and books. In the area of the cabin closest to the door was a kitchenette with a cooking pot and fire.

"Wonderful!" exclaimed Tucker. "William, come over here." He gestured to one of the shelves and William approached it. "As a reward for saving me, I'll let you have any item on this shelf here. Anything you want! Go ahead! Pick one!"

William examined the shelves. There was many random odds and ends on it. They all looked quite exquisite and rare. Any of them would easily fetch a fair price in the markets. He had his eye on a particular item, a golden egg with hundreds of tiny gems embedded in it. He was about to reach for it when he felt a strong strike on his neck, and the fox blacked out as he landed on the floor with thud.

Our aspiring adventure woke up several hours later on a bed in a dark room. The first thing that William noticed was a heavy metal cuff attached to his left leg. The cuff was connected to a rusty chain that to a metal loop embedded in the stone wall. All of the walls in this room were stone, William noted.

The fox slowly got off the bed, cradling his pained neck with his left hand. The room was largely empty. Only stone, chains, a bed, and stone staircase leading to a wooden door on the opposite side of the room. It was too far away from William to reach while attached to the chain. "Tucker!" cried William. "Tucker, are you there?"

After a few minutes the wooden door to William's cell swung open and Tucker sauntered in. "Oh hey, you're awake!" said Tucker. "I hope I didn't hit you too hard there. I just wanted you out for a few minutes while I brought you down to your new quarters."

"What are you doing, you jerk?" asked William. "Just give me my reward and let me go!"

Tucker chuckled to himself. "Oh, there was never any reward. I just used that as an excuse to bring you here. Well, there is a reward if you consider being my experiment a reward."

"Experiment? What are you talking about?"

"I'm an adventurer too, William. And from my adventures, I've acquired many treasures. But a lot of them have magical properties, and these magical properties are only known when they are applied to an individual. So I don't really know the true power of what I find until I try it one someone."

"Like that belt?" asked William.

Tucker smirked. "Just like that belt. I got impatient and tried it on myself. It was only a stroke of luck that you came along to help. Imagine, though, if I had someone to try it on for me first. Imagine if I had a fox like you to try it on. I'd know the powers of that belt without you smashing it up. Sure, I would have a massive fox to deal with, but I'd find some other uses for you."

"So you want to use me like a lab rat?"

"Lab FOX." Tucker replied.

"I don't want to be a lab fox!" yelled William.

"You sure? Because I could just bring you right back to those woods and let those Syrup Vines loose on you. And you'll regret your decision as you pop from all their syrup." Tucker got really close to William. "They'll balloon you up. And when you beg for them to stop, they'll keep pumping you even bigger." He leaned into William's ear. "And you'll beg to be my lab...fox again."

William was stuck between a rock and a hard place. The only thing he could do was agree to be Tucker's lab rat until he found a way to escape his cell.

"Fine...fine." William resigned.

"Excellent!" Tucker marched back upstairs and, after a few minutes, came back down with something in each hand. "You'll learn that I can be nice to you. And as a start, I'll let you pick the first thing to try on you!" He held open both of his palms. In his left paw was something that looked like a large bee stinger. William heard of legends of massive bees building colonies in the distant plans, but he only thought of them as legends. In Tucker's right paw was a perfect green cube. The cube was translucent and William was able to see right through it.

What does William pick?
1122221.title: Accept Tucker's Reward

choices: Try to find a safer area
1123.content:
William didn't want to take the risk in trying to snatch up the items. Instead, the fox decided to sneak away and not aggravate the Syrup Vines. But as he turned around to run, a lone Syrup Vine surprise attacked William. It leaped onto his face, wrapping its vine body around the fox's head. William felt a loose vine force its way into his maw and toward his throat. The fox tried biting down hard onto the vine, but the root was too thick for him to gnaw through.

As William tried to pry the Syrup Vine from his face, thick liquid began to fill his belly. Every second, the fox's flat stomach bloated out, stretching his tunic and wearing out the seams. The shirt started riding up his ballooning gut as William continued to try and rip the Syrup Vine off of him.

Nothing that he did was working. Biting, clawing, nothing was hurting the Syrup Vine. His stomach was reaching its bursting point. The tunic was no longer bothered to cover the nearly two foot wide sphere of orange and white fur swelling on his midsection.

The pressure was almost too much for William to handle. And none of his attacks were working against the Syrup Vine. The fox resigned himself to fate. He'll painfully blow up into a giant furry balloon until he popped in a massive explosion of syrup.

Right when William felt like he was about to pop, the Syrup Vine suddenly let go. It pulled the vine from the fox's mouth, detached itself from William's face, and scurried away. The creature had run dry, clearly having emptied most of its liquid into the other unlucky traveler beforehand.

William glanced down at his poor, extended gut. Never before had he seen his stomach this large. It has also never been so full. Gently rubbing a paw along the tight skin of his stomach, the fox evaluated his situation. He needed to rest his inflated gut, but the area might not be completely safe. If he stayed and rested, more of the Syrup Vines might show up.

What does William do?
1123.title: Surprise! The vines got the jump on William.

12.content:
William began to trudge into the green fields that surrounded the city's east side, trying to recall all of the information he had gotten out of the local townspeople before setting off. The caves, he remembered, were sometimes infested with small candy-slime monsters intent on making themselves be eaten, though many of the caverns were stocked with gold, supplies and occasionally magic and wondrous items. The open fields were stalked by wild predators looking to find new meals to make themselves even fatter; strange mutations made some of the critters' claws contain a weight-gaining effect if they landed a scratch. The hills further south contained small villages with renowned eating festivals complete with contests. To the east, a mysterious village loomed. Few ventured to go there; rumors of curses abounded throughout the land. Finally, a small shopping center right outside the city offered unique booths with magic trinkets for purchase.

After a few seconds of consideration, William decided to try...
12.title: Into the Green Fields

choices: ...A small item, which looked sort of like candy.
121.content:
William decided to go into the caves. He only had a rusted sword and he figured that there were amazing things to find in the caves, despite the risks.

He continued on his way until he finally arrived at the entrance to the cave. He looked back at the sunlight behind him. It was so warm and inviting, while the cave ahead spelled nothing but danger and darkness. Sucking up his courage, he lit his torch and made his way into the cave.

William was holding his torch as he went along, when he came along a small cavern and saw...
121.title: The Candy Caves.

choices: A monster from the depths of the cave
1211.content:
As William waved his torched, he noticed that its light glimmered off of something in the distance. He cautiously made his way further into the cave trying to figure out what it was. He discovered that it was, in fact, a sword that the torch's light was bouncing off of. The sword, however, was lounged deep into the wall of the cave. But from what William could make out, the blade of the sword was shiny and new. Clearly, it must be sharp enough to cut deep into whatever these cave walls were made of. The handle of the sword was gold and encrusted with large gems.

Finding this sword was a brilliant stroke of good luck for a new adventurer like William. Thought he recognized the importance of his own rusted sword, it would hardly protect him in battle. But a new sword like this would allow him to challenge all sorts of opponents he may meet.

William set his torch down in a place where it would be safe and still light the cave. He gripped the sword stuck in the cave wall and started the pull. After giving the attempt some considerable amount of energy, the sword remained just as stuck as it was. William gave it several more tried before concluding that getting that sword free would take something more than just elbow grease.

But as William tried to step away from the sword, he realized that somehow his hands were stuck to the blade's handle. William began to panic as he realized his situation. He was no longer concerned about getting that sword and he was he was more focused on making sure he doesn't spend the rest of his life attached to that sword.

While William was desperately trying to free himself, something was approaching him from behind. What was approaching William?
1211.title: ...A sword, stuck in a stone.

choices: decided to enjoy himself and let the bugs feed themselves to him...
tried to fight back but was overwhelmed...
1212.content:
William held his torch up to the brightly colored item which lay on the floor in front of him. It was small, less than an inch in length, and was decorated with a pink and yellow swirl. Curiously, William reached his hand down towards the item and it twitched. William reached again and it jumped away from him. "Hey!" he shouted as he followed the strange thing deeper into the cave.

The item scurried around a corner and into a dead end. As William turned he saw it climb up a wall, and on that wall other brightly colored stones with playful patterns adorned the wall like gems. A hissing sound echoed throughout the chamber and without warning small, spider-like legs extended from one of the "candies". The candybug, for that is what it was, leapt onto William's chest and crawled up onto his face. William's mouth opened up in horror, and the candybug crawled in.

William's mouth filled up with a sweet taste, much like candy, as other candybugs assaulted him. In the wake of this, William...
1212.title: William's first battle

choices: William was able to escape the Queen Candybug
William was not able to escape the Queen Candybug
12121.content:
As the sweet taste of the candybug filled his mouth, he realized that hundreds of other candybugs had emerged from the depths of the caves. William knew that he wouldn't be able to fight them off; a sword would hardly be able to strike these tiny creatures. However, it didn't seem like the candybugs did anything that harmful.

As several dozen candybugs crawled up his body, William did nothing to fight them off. Instead, he opened his maw and welcomed the critters. Five of the candybugs crawled into his mouth and he crunched down on them, an explosion of sweetness happened in his mouth. He eagerly picked off a few that were making their way up his chest and tossed them into his mouth, and William moaned because of the delicious taste. He kept popping more and more of them into his mouth, each tasting just as wonderful as the last. William got on his hands and knees and began eat the candybugs straight off the floor. They amassed in front of him waiting to be eaten by the fox.

After what seemed like hours, William was picking off the last of the candybugs. Munching down on the last one in sight, he moaned and rubbed is swollen, distended belly. All the hundreds, or perhaps thousands, of candybugs bloated William's belly and made it look as if he had swallowed a beach ball. His normally flat midsection was now a pudgy sphere that was trying to digest the thousands of calories worth of candybugs he just ate. William had never been this full before, especially not with such sweet critters. Thanks to that, he found it hard to move around. He gently waddled over to one of the cave walls and sat down against it, letting his massive gut push apart his legs.

William was softly rubbing his belly and his eyes were heavy with sleep. He thought that perhaps a quick nap would help him digest. But as William drifted off to sleep, he heard several incredibly loud thuds off in the distance. Worried, William tried getting himself back onto his feet, but his sizable paunch kept weighing him down. More loud thuds happened, and whatever was making them was getting closer to William, and this panicked him.

Making several more failed attempted at getting back onto this feet, William knew that it was futile. Right in front of his was the Queen of the Candybugs. She looked much like a regular candybug except several thousand times bigger.

William was unsure what the Queen Candybug would do, but he need to get out of there now. Was William able to escape?
12121.title: decided to enjoy himself and let the bugs feed ...

choices: A large, pink slime coming towards him
A flowing river of chocolate milk
12122.content:
The fox clawed at the candybugs trying to crawl into this mouth. The torch's light didn't extend very far, but William could see thousands of the creatures heading towards him. If he let all of them into his belly, he'd surely explode. Rather than trying to defeat all these opponents, the best William could hope for was to escape unharmed.

Swinging his sword, William swiped at the candybugs skittering towards him. Knocking back dozens at time, William began his retreat. Yet his attacks were useless. The candybugs were starting to overwhelm his. Other candybugs were crawling on top of each other to get to him.

Rather than trying to keep up the fight, William decided that running away would be his best option. He turned around and started to spirit into the deep darkness of the cave. This was successful since the candybugs could not keep up with his speed.

William turned his head during his escape and saw that no more of the candybugs were closely following him. Suddenly, the fox felt that he was falling. The torchlight didn't let him see much of what was ahead, but when he had briefly looked away, William didn't see the cliff that his path turned into.

Seconds, minutes, hours? William wasn't sure how long he was falling. What he did know was the hard, cold surface his slammed into which knocked him unconscious.

After some time, William awoke. His body was sore because of the fall, but he couldn't feel any major injuries aside from some nasty bumps any bruises. The extinguished torch laid on the ground next to him. The fox reignited it to get a sense of his bearings, and the first thing he saw was...
12122.title: William Successfully Runs Away

choices: William drinks more from the river
121222.content:
He reignited is torch and raised it high trying to get a sense of his new surrounds. William didn't notice anything particularly strange, but he did hear the faint sound of water rushing off in the distance. The fox headed towards the sound, being particularly careful about where he was stepping. He didn't need a repeat of his last incident.

Ten minutes later, William saw a raging river in front of him. As he approached it, he recognize two things. First, the river flowed much more slowly than any river he has seen before. It was as if the water was somehow thicker. The second thing that William noticed was the dark brown color of the water. It didn't look dirty, rather, the liquid had a consist light brown color, as if it was made out of...

"Chocolate?" William asked himself.

The fox approached the river and knelt down. He sniffed the liquid and, sure enough, it had a distinct chocolate odor to it. After planting the torch into a secure position nearby, he returned to the river and knelt down again. Dipping a pawful into the liquid, he cupped out a bit of the river and raised it to his mouth. A cautious tongue drank in the liquid.

"Oh my God, this is chocolate milk." said William. "And it's delicious!"

William brought his face to the river and began lapping up the liquid. Sweet chocolate goodness filled his mouth and then it filled his belly. The fox kept lapping up more and more of the chocolate river completely lost in the ecstasy.

It was only when his belly felt ready to burst that William stopped drinking the river up. He arose from the lake and noticed how much his gut stuck out, several inches larger than usual thanks to the chocolate milk that the fox had sucked up. The pain of his fullness suddenly set in, and the fox took a paw and rubbed his swollen gut. William's belly stretched his tunic tight, showing off the outline of his belly button. He moved around gently and swore he could he the sounds of sloshing in his gut followed by the sound of seams groaning under pressure. Despite the pain, he was hooked and wanted even more. But then again, another ounce more and the fox will surely burst.
121222.title: Chocolate River

choices: William just wants to get the hell out of here.
William decides to examine the wolves and maybe snag a couple of trophies...
Well, it looks like there's something else coming his way...
122.content:
William decides to head out into the fields, because... Well, why not?

He wades out into the verdant knee-high grass, taking care not to step on whatever might be hiding beneath the cover. Whether it be a monster or a cow-pat, he doesn't want to step on either. After a mile or so into the field without incident, he decides to let his guard down. He's not seen any cows around... Nor has he seen any monsters. In fact, if there were any monsters, they'd probably be too large to hide amongst the grass blades. The fox carries onward, just a bit more nonchalant, but still wary of his surroundings.

Despite being such a supposedly dangerous place, William's finding himself growing rather bored in the Fattening Fields. It's been all of an hour since he'd set off on his aimless quest, and he's spent forty minutes of that hour milling about some empty plains. The orange fox sighs in frustration, but keeps on walking. Might as well, right?

A few hundred feet more reward William with a small "island" out in the middle of this sea of grass. A small bit of raised land lies in front of him, simply made of dirt. Atop this "hill" of three feet is a small boulder and what appears to be an oak tree. He decides that this spot would probably be a good place to take a short break. The fox perches himself atop the boulder and stares out into grassy expanse that he's yet to walk through. He sees grass,,, More grass... A slightly-yellowed patch of grass... Even more grass, and... Hello, what's this?

Out in the distance, William finally sees something vaguely interesting: A pack of dire wolves chasing a deer. The wolves were all quite large, both in terms of weight and overall size. Each wolf appeared to stand about as tall as a horse, with a body length proportional to that... But were also about as wide as they were tall, it seemed. The deer was your standard-sized doe, of course, albeit with a few hundred more pounds of flesh added to its frame. As William watched the spectacle, he noted that this "chase" wasn't much of a chase at all; both the wolves and deer were merely waddling along, getting slower as the seconds passed.

The deer eventually came to a stop as soon as it could no longer stand running, rolling over on its side and panting. This, of course, spelled its doom, as the wolves began surrounding the helpless creature. They each raised a claw into the air and struck the deer wherever they could, making it cry out in pain. At this point, William noted that the wolves' claws were especially interesting: Each paw was colored gold, with purple claws extending from the digits. There were rather long claws, but that was to be expected of a dire wolf.

William wondered if these were the "mutant claws" you'd been told about. As the deer began to swell like bread-dough before the fox's eyes, this was confirmed. The wolves kept jabbing the deer in the gut, and it kept fattening, it's neck becoming lost in rolls of fat along with all of its legs. When the deer had become a giant beige blob, twice as tall as any of the wolves, they were satisfied. William looked on with morbid fascination as the "lead" wolf set to work killing the deer as three others latched onto the deer's mammoth gut, pulling at it as it wobbled and quivered wildly like an overfull sack of gelatin. The doe cried out in pain once more as the leader sank his teeth into her throat to land the killing blow... But failed, as there was far too much fat to bite through.

The wolf kept trying and trying, but couldn't locate the doe's jugular. He eventually gave up and joined the other dire-wolves, taking another section of jiggling, cream-colored belly-flesh and pulling in another direction. The deer kicked her fat-addled legs feebly, but you could tell it was simply giving up as the wolves continued gnawing at her bloated gut, jostling it and jiggling it all about until it tore open bloodlessly. The doe moaned one last time and went still, leaving the wolves to feast upon the vast stores of fat they'd made within her belly.

Not wanting to alert these vicious beasts to his presence, William stayed where he was, watching with a mixture of disgust, fear... And hunger, as the wolves gorged themselves upon the deer's blubbery carcass. As time went on, you could see the wolves themselves swelling with new fat. After what seemed like an hour, the wolves slow in their feasting, each withdrawing from the half-eaten body and plodding a few feet away, where they all collapsed into the grass and fell into a deep sleep.

"Well," William said to himself. "I doubt they'll be bothering me, now."

William lowered himself from his boulder and got ready to set off into the fields once more. Where to? That's a good question.
122.title: The Fields Where they Feed

choices: Eat some of the wild fruit
1221.content:
Although William was fascinated with how the deer's body had bloated up to massive proportions, he wasn't inserted himself with becoming the victim of the dire wolves. Setting off in the opposite direction of the hunt, William made his way deeper into the grasslands.

The aspiring adventurer was able to travel through the plains for quite some time without any disturbances. Aside from spotting the occasional pack of rotund wild deer, there were not many other creatures around. In fact, there wasn't much of anything else in the area aside from tall, waist-high grass and the occasional barren tree.

That is, there wasn't much else until William stumbled upon a kind of oasis. There was a sizable lake of clear, crisp water. Surrounding the lake were various different bushes and tree, some of which had ripe, plump fruits hanging from the branches.

William approached the oasis. A lone wild deer was drinking from the lake. It spotted him and waddled away, the deer's flabby flanks and rump wobbling violently as it trotted away.

Noticing the girth of the deer, William was struck with a thought: How did wildlife out here get so plump? The dire wolves clearly got huge from fattening up their prey and gorging themselves on its blubber. But deer only ate plants and drank water. So how was it that an herbivore blew up to be several hundred pounds?

A good question, but William didn't want to waste time theorizing right now. Instead, he wanted to take advantage of the situation. He was feeling particular thirsty and hungry from the traveling he did, so it would serve William well to utilize the resources he just found. What does he do first?
1221.title: William just wants to get the hell out of here.

choices: William didn't notice a creature approaching him from behind
12211.content:
William was quite hungry, but it had been so incredibly long since he had a drink of water. And the water that made up the oasis' lake looked so crisp and clear that he couldn't resist taking at least a few sips.

Approaching the lake, William set his sword beside him on the ground. He got down to his knees, took a pawful of water from the lake, and raised it to his muzzle. He tounged the liquid from his paw. It tasted cool and fresh. Although William knew of the risks of drinking raw water, he figured that the lake was pure enough that he wouldn't have to worry about getting sick or catching some disease from it. Getting down on all fours, he stuck his muzzle into the lake and began swallowing large mouthfuls of the fresh water, and the liquid started filling his empty belly.
12211.title: Drink from the Oasis

1222.content:
William with a hint of interest decided that he would slowly sneak over to the dire wolves and see if they have anything that he could use or sell. He got a better look at them and saw that even though they were already so fat, they had gained a considerable amount of fat on their frames. William looked around for anything and at last he found something.

         He walked over to the object and when he reached it he got a good idea what it was It was a claw from one of the dire wolves. He picked up the purple claw and wondered it it had any of its magical properties. He decided to test it out on the wolves by lightly poking one of the smallest wolves which looked to be the only one that was still mobile with the claw.

         Almost immediately after poking the wolf with the claw the wolf's belly began to growl and gurgle. By the time the wolfs frame stopped expanding his mobility was lost. William decided to see if it affected the whole body or just the part that he poked.

         He decided to use the same wolf as a test subject again but this time instead of poking the wolf in the belly he poked him in the butt. Immediately the wolfs slightly round butt ballooned with magic fat from the claw. William lightly felt the wolfs butt and it began to grow.It stopped growing and it felts so suishy and bigg, By now his butt looked like two beach balls.

He turned around and noticed something that was the size of a cat. He slowly and silently crept over the shadow and parted some ferns. Behind them was something that amazed you It was a dire wolf cub. William quietly awed at the sight of the chubby little wolf and wondered how he missed the little thing.

To take the little wolf with him and fatten all the rest of the wolves till bursting and keep the wolf as his pet.

And his last option was to:
Fatten all of the pack except the little wolf cub and take him home where he would be fattened to immobility.Then william would keep harvesting the little wolfs claws and sell most of them

He escaped the den back to the fields

William looked over his handiwork as he stared at all the wolves. Each one was immobile now and still fast asleep. Using his lithe frame, he quickly and quietly cut off the claws of the wolves and stored them in his pouch. After he had them he snuck off until...
12221.title: First option

choices: put some meat on the pups bones
name the chubby and little ball of fur
12222.content:
William decided to keep the little wolf as a pet since he was living alone. William walked close to the wolf and approached it. Claw in hand William was ready for the little wolf pup to attack him, but nothing happened. William got so close that he could pick up the little wolf in his paws. William hefted the chubby ball of fur in his arms and began to scratch its belly. It began to relax on Mikes arms and William squeezed some of the tiny fat rolls that were forming on the feral dire wolf.

         William gently set the little wolf pup down on the ground and began on his plan to fatten up all of the dire wolfs till they explode. Willi again walked over to the dire wolfs and chose to return to the first dire wolf and thought that this would be you’re first victim. William looked at the young wolf and had another idea and this one the young pup would have someone to play with.

William thought about what to do for a second and fin lay decided to put some meat on the young dire wolfs bones.          William walked into town and walked over to the mages guild and sold all of the claws for five thousand gold pieces. William then wanted to buy two collars for the two wolves. Which item does William choose?

William glanced from the slime to the enhancing potion.William decided that the potion would be more interesting. William pulled the cork off of the purple vile and drank it. 122222.content:
William petted the wolf pup on the head, enjoying the pup's company. He thought for a moment, thinking of a name, and decided on one.

"I'm gonna name you Blubberclaw. Cause you're such a cute ball of blubber, and your claws makes thing blubbery."

The pup rolled around on the grass as William began scratching his tummy. Blubberfang kicked his leg, enjoying the scratching, then got up to walk over to the immobile Dire Wolf. It was still sleeping, unknowing of what happened to its pack, and its fate. William laughed a little as he got up and walked to his back door.

"You want something, Blubberclaw?" he asked.

The little wolf pup barked as it bounded towards him. William smiled as he opened the door, letting the ball of fat come inside. His home was small and meager, but William liked it because it was cozy. He grabbed a plate and placed some strips of beef on it, setting it on the ground. Blubberclaw yelped as he bounded to the food, and began to eat. William smiled as he opened his back, seeing his collection of the purple claws.

"I'm going to go sell these and make some cash. You behave while I'm gone, alright?"

Blubberclaw didn't stop eating. William giggled as he walked to the front door, and headed out.

-----

William headed into town, seeing an apothecary nearby. He entered the building, seeing a middle-aged crow anthro manning the store. This was Uncle Hem, and he's friendly to everyone. He always likes having everyone call him uncle, and takes care of the townspeople, including William. When the crow looked up, he saw the young fox approach, and smiled.

"Ah, William! It's been a while since I saw you. How are you?" he asked.

"I'm fine, Uncle Hem. I went out and gathered a bunch of Dire Wolf claws!"

William smiled as he dumped the contents of his bag on the counter. The crow looked down at the, and smiled at William.

"Ah, taking after your father now, are you? Hahaha! I knew you had his adventurous spirit in you! Now, let me take a look here..."

The crow took a claw and examined it. He looked at it, noting its color, tapping it on the counter, and when he was satisfied, he smiled.

"Yup! I can definitely tell these are real Dire Wolf claws! I can give you...Mm...300 gold pieces for this."

"Wow! T-thanks a lot, Uncle Hem! But, can I keep one of them?"

The crow laughed as he separated one from the pile, and took out a bag full of coins.

"Sure, sure! Just for you, William."

William thanked him as he took the bag, and stashed the single claw in his backpack. The crow waved him goodbye as he left. Now that he had some cash to burn, what should he do now?
122222.title: Blubberclaw The Dire Wolf Pup

choices: William heads South to the farm and fields
12223.content:
William decided that in order to really be an adventurer he'd need some source of income. So, with the dire wolf's claw in hand, approached the sleeping older wolves and one by one gave them gently pokes in the belly. The claw didn't have to go in deep. So long as it penetrated the skin it could send it's magic into it's victims.

With each poke, the wobbling bellies of the obese wolves grew out, jiggling and gurgling as their fat expanded. William found it curious how the dire wolves' skin stretched to accommodate for the new fat. Rings of blubber wrapped around the necks of the feral beasts and their tails sunk into growing rears. By the time William was done, each wolf was too large to move their legs, let alone escape. From there, William took the claws from the immobilized wolves.

Looking at the morbidly obese masterpieces he had left, it was no wonder to William that the kingdom had been riddled with massive obesity in the past few years. Between many seasons of rich crops, the recent mutation of the dire wolves, the use of particular magics learned from the nearby citadel's magic academy and the popular new form of battle adventurers had taken up, devouring your enemies whole, citizens and adventurers alike had a hard time living their day to day lives without earning a hefty frame. In fact, obesity was becoming a fad of sorts, as it represented a life full of adventure and success arguably just as much as a ripped muscular body. The main reason William had avoided this thus far was because his cottage was on the outskirts of the city and he tended to keep to himself.

Looking back to the no longer little wolf cub, William let out a sigh. He scooped up the blob of wobbling fur in his arms and, employing all his strength, wandered back to his house. Once he arrived to his cottage he opened the gate to his backyard. He set down his little wolf pet, who he decided to name Blubberfang as a testament to both the feisty attitude he had shown as he writhed about in William's arms and, of course, the thick padding of his blubber and the fat he could give to others.

William got to work, poking Blubberfang in the belly and butt with the claw, which was beginning to run out of juice. slowly Blubberfang's belly rose up beneath him, hoisting him into the air and splaying his legs to the sides, resting off the ground and on his stomach. His rear also grew into two perfectly round jiggling globes with a tail poking out of the crevasse in between.

William's tail swooshed side to side and he smiled as his new dire wolf pet calmed down. The soothing effects of jiggling fat on all his parts must have made him sleepy. William knew he'd have to keep Blubberfang fattened up from time to time. He wouldn't need to eat much since he was so big, but until the two had bound enough for the fox to call the dire wolf his companion he'd need to stay big enough that he wouldn't run away. Perhaps some day Blubberfang would be docile enough to be William's traveling/battle companion?

Well either way, now that William had Blubberfang safe at home, he started off into the city to see what supplies he could purchase with his claws. The trek to the city didn't take long, but once he got closer to the shopping district within the city's heart William found it harder and harder to move. The shopping district had some of the more wealthy homes of the city, and thus the citizens out and about on the streets became wider and wider as William headed in, some even taking up half the street.

William first decided to make a visit to the blacksmith's shop. The heat of the forge blasted William's fur as he entered the doorway. The blacksmith, Argus, was a tall bull with thick, beefy arms, and a large, round beer belly.. "Aye, what can I getcha?" Argus said, focusing his attention on the spearhead he was shaping. He then looked up at William, saw the rusty sword on his back and sighed. "Ah, another perspective adventurer... Do yerself a favor and see yerself out. Trust me, things are getting wild around here and you don't look like the fightin' type."

Puffing out his chest, William stepped forward and approached the counter. "Not the fighting type, huh?" He opened up his sack of dire wolf claws and dumped it on the counter. Argus put down the hammer and eyed the claws.

"Dire wolf claws, eh? Well, paint me tusks and call me a daisy! Ye might just have the fighting spirit in you." Argus picked up one of the claws and weighed it in his hand. "Yep, this seems like the real thing, but..." He gave himself a sharp poke in the stomach with the claw. His firm belly rounded out, swelling in front of him to the size of a beach ball. Argus let out a hefty laugh as he slapped his massive gut. "Haha, yes that's real alright!"

William bartered with Argus and, in exchange for half of the claws, received a well fitted chain mail suit, a higher quality steel sword and a dagger handle fitted to hold the claws of dire wolves. William then went off to sell some more claws in exchange for some food supplies (a few apples, a box of donuts and a cake) and some potions, including a few healing potions and some "deflater" potions. William had heard of many creatures out in the wild, like the syrup vines to the northern woods or the various jelly slimes from the fields to the hills, that force fed themselves to their victims in battle. The deflater potions would speed up the digestive system, quickening recovery from a deadly stuffing, although whatever was consumed would still take it's toll on the body.

Now feeling ready for true adventure, William had to decide where to continue. He could go back south to the fields and hunt the wild beasts as well as wildlings, savage magic-wielding raiders who reject society in favor of a dangerous life. Perhaps the farm there would be in need of an adventurer such as himself? He had heard Ol' Farmer Buttermilk was having trouble keeping his herd.

He could also head north into the forest. In the forest he would likely come across syrup vines, thick plants who wrapped their vines around their victims and pumped them full of syrup until they were incapacitated (or worse), or perhaps a blueberry nymph, a forest sprite who's songs could lull an adventurer into a trance in which they swelled up with juices like a blueberry until they popped. Strange, mysterious events also took place in the forest, and one could never tell whether they'd encounter a pack of wild wolves or a house made out of candy!

To the east there was the citadel, another city centered around the school of magic. It would probably cost a hefty penny to earn the cash to study magic, however the inn there would be a great place to pick up quests and the hills nearby, while holding stronger creatures than the forest or fields and perhaps being too "high level", was home to various caves and who doesn't love adventures in caves? Farther off to the east were the mountains, where the most dangerous creatures lived. William knew he wouldn't be able to take on anything there yet, but perhaps once he had grown stronger he could.

To the west there was another town by the beachside. There were also probably some quests there, and the relaxation of the sun, sand and very large coconuts sounded nice. Word was it the docks could take you to an island full of dangerous tribals, but again William doubted he was strong enough to adventure there.
12223.title: A Steady Income

122231.content:
William decided to go where the questing was ripe, and a good place for that sounded like Ol' Farmer Buttermilk's farm to the southwest of the city. So the next day, supplies in tow and having fed Blubberfang to keep him plumped up, the young fox headed out on the western road and took the bend south back towards the fields. This time, however, instead of wandering blindly into the tall wavy grass, he stayed on the path until he encountered wooden fences leading the way to a barn, a few shacks and a country style house all huddled into a homey settlement.

In a nearby corral were some of the largest cows he had ever seen, hugely round and fat with udders brushing the ground. They chewed and munched on the tall grass of the fields without a care.

Ol' Farmer Buttermilk was managing his milk stand. People came from all around to bring home his milk, some of the freshest and most definitely the creamiest around, but today there were no customers at the stand and the plump goat looked distressed.

"Mr. Buttermilk!" William called over, waving his hand as he approached.

"My my... William? Little William, is that you in all that armor? Don't tell me you've decided to take after your father now..." Ol' Farmer Buttermilk said, but through a knowing smile.

"You bet I have. And what better way to start my adventures than by helping out an important local business?" William grinned back.

"Haha, I'm glad you're here. Your father would be proud." The old goat said. "Actually, you've come at the right time. I could use a hand. Beasts have been picking off my cattle, and I ain't one to go picking a fight with a wild lion." Buttermilk shook his head in dismay.

"Lions?" William asked. Lions weren't a usual predator to the area.

"You heard me. There's lions in them fields! People say they came up north here fer the food, since eatin's been good the past decade or two. Now they're eatin' up some of the deer, even some wolves, and worst of all, my cattle! Rumor has it they ain't the only beasts out and about these days that don't belong here... But you know what I say?" He paused for a moment, then put his hands on his pudgy sides impatiently.

"No... what do you say?" William said, urging him on.

"Well," The old goat continued as if he hadn't paused, "I'd say something's urging them on. Wildlings. They've got some spooky shaman camped out somewhere and sometimes at night you can hear them chantin' strange things and see puffs of smoke in the distance. Ever since they got riled up we've been seeing all these beasts like lions and tigers and even an elephant wandering around! Do yerself a favor, boy. If you see a wildling, be careful. But I'll pay you a good price for any lion pelts you bring me! I'll even let you keep a few. Maybe you can make a cloak or something, I dunno what you adventurous types do."

William nodded, having listened to everything the farmer had to say. "Sounds like a deal. I'll do what I can, and if I see a wildling, who knows? Maybe I'll bring back it's head too!" With that, he turned and headed off to the fields, Ol' Farmer Buttermilk calling behind him.

"Don't get cocky now, boy! There's trouble brewin'!" His voice faded into the distance as William entered the fields.
122231.title: William heads South to the farm and fields

choices: ...brandished his sword, ready for the fight!
...took out his dire wolf claw dagger, hoping for an opening.
1222311.content:
Four hours had passed under the hot sun and there hadn't been any signs of a lion in the area. William did come across a few grazing deer, their wide stomachs dragging against the ground, and even another pack of dire wolves who had been too large and tired to pose a threat unless provoked, but lions? How does one even go about hunting a lion? From what William had heard, lions are more often the type to stalk and not be stalked.

Wading through the waist high grass, William saw a lone tree in the endless field. Maybe if he climbed it the extra height could let him spy something worth hunting? That was his thought as he pushed his way forward through the grass. However, as he got closer he saw a shifting shape under the shade of the leafy branches. It blended in closely with the color of the grass but it's heavy frame had flattened the nearby grass.

William froze and unsheathed his sword, clutching it in both hands. He peered over the grass and, lo and behold, a male lion lay resting in the shade, awake yet lethargic. Although not a native creature to the area, whatever time he had spent in the area had clearly been successful as he was nearly as fattened as the other animals William had seen. As he laid down on his side, the lion's belly surged forward, spreading on the ground down to his knees. Blubber encased his neck, folding into several wobbling chins that jiggled as the beast yawned and licked his greasy chops.

The lion lifted his heavy head and turned to face William and fear shot down the fox's spine. Stealth wasn't going to be an option in this battle. William...
1222311.title: William comes across a lion...

choices: William is found by a Wildling!
William turns in the hides and recieves his reward.
12223111.content:
William brandished his sword, ready for a fight. The lion, sensing the blood rushing through the fox's veins, lifted itself up and crouched, ready to strike. For a moment, time froze and the heat of the afternoon sun felt cold on William's face.

The lion's eyes glimmered and in an instant time caught up to itself and the blubbery beast leapt at William, full force. However, the weight of the lion's stomach pulled him down, and the leap only brought him just in front of William, who took a step back and swung his blade towards the beast's side. The lion veered to William's left and swiped at his chest, claws raking at the chain mail vest. William was pushed back but otherwise the attack was blocked by the armor.

Upon reeling back from his failed attack, the lion paced back and forth, breathing heavily. This gave William an idea. With agility not many beings in the kingdom knew, he darted behind the lion. The lion in turn whirled around as fast as he could, but William was swifter than this obese feline and stayed behind him. The two ran in circles around each other before the inevitable. The lion collapsed, panting and wheezing.

William took his place in hand and pierced it deep into the lion's neck, killing him instantly. He wiped his sword off on the grass and sheathed it before gutting and skinning his kill. William didn't know how much lion meat would go for in the market, but any slab of meat thick with fat was highly prized (as was any food high in fat content) lately. The hide itself was pretty large, and William was sure Ol' Farmer Buttermilk would have plenty of uses for it.

Having taken all the loot from the fallen beast he could, William continued his hunt. By the time the sun began to set he had found and slain three more lions, totaling up to four kills and a lot of loot. William headed back towards the farm...
12223111.title: William, Lion's Bane

choices: The two anthros duel it out.
The shaman knocks William unconcious with a spell.
122231111.content:
As William plodded through the tall grassy fields, grunting from the heavy load of meat and furs in his backpack, he heard a low grumble from somewhere nearby. Looking around, the fox's attention was caught by a patch of weeds that seemed... off. His tracking skills told him that something had been through there recently. Grabbing his sword by the hilt, he cautiously parted through the grass, following the trail back to the tree where he found the first lion.

There, crouched over the corpse of the bloated beast was a wiry, sun-beaten anthro horse. The horse was the thinnest man William had seen in a long time. Each bone of his spine poked out, threatening to break through the tight skin which wrapped his body like a dry rubber band. His ribs showed and his stomach caved in. If the horse had eaten in the past few days it had been meagerly. In his right hand he clutched a sturdy looking walking cane of sorts.

However, instead of cutting a slice of spare meat from the lion's haunches (there was a lot of meat left), the horse stirred his hand in the exposed fat of the beast and let out strange slurred words. He scooped out a small amount of fat and smeared it across his face. Then, a green stone at the tip of the gnarled cane glowed softly. It shook for a moment, rattling the cane like a stiff breeze, and a green light the size of a golf ball sprung out of the stone like a spark from a flame. It hovered about the horse for a moment, floating like a lazy firefly. Then, without warning, it shot out, smacking William into the chest and vanishing.

The frail horse leaped up with agile grace surpassing his age and he spun around, clutching his cane in both hands. Green fire blazed in his eyes. William understood that this horse was a wildling shaman, one of the dangerous tribals who fled into the wilderness, shunning society, looting and attacking civilians at random. Wildlings were unpredictable, and the shaman were their magic-wielding leaders. William dropped his backpack and brandished his sword. This was going to be one hell of a fight.
122231111.title: William is found by a Wildling!

choices: ...reached into his pocket and pulled out... a cupcake?
1222311111.content: In a flash the wildling shaman rushed at William, swinging his cane furiously. He swooped the end of it down at William's head, but the fox parried the blow with his sword. Despite the blow of the sharp metal, the cane held it's own with barely a scratch. William came back at the shaman with a swing, but the blow was blocked by the horse's twirling cane, acting as a shield. As William recoiled from the block, the wildling...
1222311111.title: Dueling with a Shaman

choices: ...grunted in pain (it was an attack spell)
...felt a gurgling in his stomach (it was a...different spell)
12223111111.content: The stone in the shaman's staff shifted in color, the green suddenly appearing liquid and inverting in on itself like a whirlpool and leaving a haze or purple. Out of the stone flew a bolt of glowing purple mist, which hit William square in the chest. William...
12223111111.title: Mysterious Magic

choices: William attempts to resist and block the cupcakes.
William gives in and devours as many cupcakes as possible.
12223111112.content:
As William recoiled from the block, the wildling reaching into his pocket and pulled out a simple cupcake. The cupcake didn't look special. It was just a simple chocolate cupcake, no wrapper, pink frosting and some sprinkles.

Confused, William stood dumfounded for a moment, which was all the time the shaman needed to hurl the cupcake straight at William's face. The cupcake slid past the fox's lips and down his throat with unnatural ease and landed in his stomach. The taste of the frosting lingered in on his tongue, taunting him and he found himself wishing he had the time to really taste it. His stomach growled, and William felt... hungry.

The wildling raised his staff and from his pockets a swarm of cupcakes rose. At the sight of them William's stomach growled once more and he found himself wanted to devour them all. In the back of his mind he screamed out that this was a trap, a trick caused by the shaman to incapacitate him. He had little time to think, however, as the cupcakes rushed at him.
12223111112.title: ...reached into his pocket and pulled out... a ...

choices: ...he had devoured them all, and got to his feet, satisfied.
122231111122.content:
Overcome by hunger, WIlliam fell to his knees and opened in jaw wide. One by one the cupcakes flew into his greedy mouth. William relished in wanton joy as the tasty treats slid down his tongue. coating the inside of his mouth in sweet, sublime pink sugar. As each cupcake flew into William's mouth he felt his stomach grow fuller and fuller, and soon past full.

In his haze of gluttony, William could not notice that he was slowly putting on weight, mostly in his stomach. His once flat belly now distended slightly. Hie sides thickened into slight love handles and his rear grew rounder. His chest became poofy and soft. Perhaps he would have noticed if his armor, made of local steel and designed to work with the often expanding forms of the locals, did not expand as well to accommodate his size.

The cupcakes kept flying at William until...
122231111122.title: William gives in and devours as many cupcakes a...

choices: The shaman let out a hearty, warm laugh and grinned.
1222311111221.content: A final cupcake flew into the hungry maw of William. The fox licked his chops and returned to his feet. Only now did he realize just how large he had become. The swarm of cupcakes had added roughly 40 pounds onto his frame. Shocked, William pushed his belly with his hand through the metal of his armor. Although he felt very, VERY full, he could tell there was definitely some extra softness, enough to give him a small overhand. His jaw dropped as he jiggled his small belly. He only remembered about the shaman when he heard a scuffling from that direction.
1222311111221.title: ...he had devoured them all, and got to his fee...

choices: "I'll need some time to think about it..."
12223111112212.content:
The horse smiled at a confused William, who in turn gave a bewildered scowl. "What did you do to me?" William shouted.

For the first time the wildling spoke. "Me? I did nothing. You gave into the trial, and passed!" He dropped his staff and knelt on one knee. "Congratulation!"

"Trial?" William was lost. "Those cupcakes were a trial?"

"Yes, either you would be overwhelmed and suffer or you would conquer, devour and come out victorious! Most are unable to complete the trial. Truly you could be the one my people have waited for! Come with me, child, for there are many things in this world you are yet to learn." The old horse picked up his staff and began to walk away.

Just before the shaman got out of sight William snapped to attention. "Hey! Wait up!" William called after him and bounded off in his direction. By the time he had caught up he was unusually winded. Not too winded, given his good physical condition prior to his sudden weight gain, but still a little out of breath. "What's going on? I thought you were a wildling or something!" The two began to walk side by side.

The old horse chuckled, shaking his head, his grey mane waving in the warm wind."I suppose I am, if that's what they call us these days. Let me guess, they told you we were vicious... bloodthirsty killers... we want nothing to do with society... and if let loose upon the world we would have everyone living in huts, brawling with each other over scraps."

"Yeah, that's what everyone says. I didn't even know you spoke the common tongue!"

"Well of course we do!" The shaman bonked William on the head with his staff. "What else would we speak! We're all natives from around here."

"But how do you explain all the raiding? The killing?" William asked warily as he rubbed his head.

"That... That you'll understand once you know who we really are." He stopped just then and turned to William. "I can take you no further. Not until you decide whether or not you want to go down this path. If you choose to return, you may go back to how things were and forget all of today's events. If you choose to stay, however, you will begin to see this world in it's true form, understand wonders beyond any story, and experience the adventures only wide eyed children dream of!" The shaman's eyes flashed with excitement.

William took a deep breath and replied...
12223111112212.title: A New Door Opens

choices: William goes to meet with the Chieftan.
William goes back home for now.
122231111122122.content:
"I'm in." William replied. The horse smiled and nodded. He then led William further down a path William could not discern. Along the way, the two talked about many things. The shaman revealed his name to be Barga, and he was a high councilor among what he called The Stewards.

When William asked what The Stewards are, Barga told him "The Stewards are what you would call the 'wildlings'. We watch over this land in earnest, keep it fertile and giving, and promote the growth of life."

"That's nothing like what I've heard..." William shook his head.

"Well we aren't exactly a public presence," Barga said. "Often our newer recruits get a little overzealous when dealing with poachers like yourself."

"Me?"

"When I found you, you were going around killing lions left and right, disturbing the balance. Not that it can be held against you, who knows so little."

"Those lions were eating up the local cows," William retorted.

"Those cows were producing plenty of excess, and enough children to resupply their population several times over. Your farmer friend simply saw a loss of profit. What he did not see was the lions' need for food. Should the lions be deprived of cows, they will go after the wolves, and should the wolves begin to die out the smaller critters will grow out of control, devouring the plantlife with abandon. Then the forests themselves suffer." Barga closed his eyes and sighed.

"Wow... I hadn't realized..." William trailed off.

"No, of course you didn't. But you will." Just over the horizon William began to see tents made of various skins, dried and pulled taut. "Welcome to The Garden, home of The Stewards." Barga said.

As William and Barga walked though the camp, William noted how many of The Stewards looked like average people. Generally, the population seemed less fattened, but there were a few chubby and even obese members of the community. Children ran around, mothers gathered by fires chatting, fathers tossed around stuffed skins in some sport. Some buildings were made of wood, some of stone, although none showed the grandiose of the city. The one thing that really stood out was a large stone statue in the village center.

"This," Barga said, gazing up at the statue, "is the reason why we are here. This is Aminas, God of Life."

The statue depicted a sprite-like being of ambiguous gender. It had a pair of wings, one like a bird and one like a bat, short wavy hair, a pointed chin, emerald eyes and long limbs. The most prominent feature of the statue was it's large, rotund frame. Aminas' belly distended down to it's knees, round and soft looking despite it's stone reality. The arms of the statue were thick with fat and the rear drooped in it's own overhang.

"Animas, God of Life, is the one The Stewards are sworn to. Through Animas, we have made this land strong and good. Without Animas, there would be no life here. After just a few years, we have accomplished so much..."

"Animas..." William repeated. "Just what have you accomplished?"

"Well this, for one." Barga poked William in the belly. "Fat, corpulence, adipose. It is all the physical manifestation of Animas' will. As life within the land grows, food and bounty becomes more and more plentiful. In turn, the creatures of the land grow fatter. Just think, in the past few years the kingdom has grown fatter practically overnight! All without changing the composition of the wildlife or the crops grown. The fields simply produce more. It is the loving will of Animas' that the children of the land reap the benefits of the earth. Animas even granted us the blessing of the sacred wolves, those who produce growth from nothing."

William rubbed his belly. "So then that trial..."

Barga nodded. "The trial was also the will of Animas. You were presented with a blessed excess of nourishment and absorbed all of it, accepting it as part of your being. It is said that among the select few who pass the trial, one shall rise to be the champion of Animas and lead the world into a new age where all life blooms! That is our mission, and you," he turned to William, "could be that hero. Maybe. There are other aspirants."

"Wait, how come not everyone in here is super fat then?" William asked.

Barga laughed out loud. "Well, not everyone has as strong an appetite as a champion eater! And as an elder high councilor, I'm sworn to delivering life and growth unto others. I may partake in the sacred growth when the world shares in the glory we know."

Having learned many things about The Stewards, William was told he was free to come and go as he wished. However, should he want to lend a hand and persue the path of the aspirant champion of Animas, there were always quests to pick up.
122231111122122.title: The Stewards

choices: William "relieves" himself before seeing the chieftain.
William goes directly to see the chieftain, boner and all.
1222311111221221.content:
William spent the night in one of the tents in The Garden. It was warm and humid, and smelt of smoke, but the fox fell asleep soon enough. In his sleep, he dreamed of a garden, not "The Garden" where he was, but a palatial garden with stone paths and trees reaching up to a black sky where stars and the sun coexisted. Each stone on the path he walked was not held in place by earth, but floated as if there was no ground beneath. Looking around, William leaned in and studied how each tree and flower pulsed with energy, waving and swaying to an unknown heartbeat.
.
The path stretched on, and as William floated along a gentle hum filled him. Streams of clean, glittering waters appeared, flowing from a source further down the path. A breeze blew by, ruffling William's fur. The waters met in the center of the garden, where seven streams and seven paths met. The branches of the trees intertwined overhead, swaying against each other like so many hands grasping each other in friendship. The roots rose from the ground making steps in this gazebo of sorts, and in the heart of it all was a marble fountain, simple and clean. Atop the fountain, above where the waters flowed from, was a flower, rich in color and fragrance. Each petal was a hundred colors and from each pistil poured golden nectar into seven cups, which overflowed into the streams.

William reached a hand out and grasped a cup. He lifted it and drank from it. The nectar was neither sweet nor sour, but it's taste filled his senses in a way not physical. As he drank, his frame swelled out, gurgling and bubbling with fat. Soft flesh expanded in all directions, dozens of pounds each second. William's belly pressed against the fountain and the waters ran against it, causing him to shiver in delight. His soft moobs rested on his chest, ample and squishy, each the size of a stack of pancakes. His rear rounded out, each cheek surpassing the size of his head and becoming dimpled with cellulite. His legs became thick so that his thighs folded over his knees to overtake them as did his arms at the elbows.

When the cup was empty William stopped to feel himself jiggle, swaying in the breeze. He placed back the cup and instantly it was full again. Excitement filled William, knowing that if he wished, he could drink from the nectar forever and always grow fatter. It was a feeling that he had never experienced before. Such a desire to stay and grow, to drink and be one with this flower.

As he reached for the cup again, however, his eyes opened and he was once again in the tent. Sunlight pierced through the entrance flap, striking him in the eyes. William rose quickly, eager to discuss his dream with Barga.

He found the old man sitting by the statue of Animas, meditating. William skid to a stop when he realized he was interrupting, but that didn't stop him from knocking over an empty bucket and causing a small clamor. Barga's eyebrow twitched, he peered over towards William and chucked. "Come to tell me about your dream with the fountain, young one?"

William stammered for a bit. "You, you knew I had the dream? How?"

"All aspirants have the dream of Animas' fountain when they come to realize their calling. And they all have the same reaction too..." His voice trailed off as his gaze shifted down. William hadn't noticed until then that the entire time he had a rather strong erection pounding against his pants. "Yes, the young aspirant usually feels the desire of Animas' will with their ENTIRE being!"

William blushed hearing this. "So... so what does this mean?"

"Oh, I think you know," Barga responded. "I've made the chieftain aware of your arrival. He told me that should you hear the calling, and it certainly seems you did, that you are welcome to enter his tent so he may tell you how you may proceed from here. Although, if I were you, I'd... relieve myself first," He said delicately. William cocked his head, unsure, so Barga elaborated. "The chieftain is the leader of The Stewards, both literally and symbolically. Thus, he DOES benefit above all others from the blessings of Animas. Most aspirants get a little... antsy when they see him for the first time, and he hasn't gotten any less blessed!" Barga laughed out loud. "The chieftain's tent is the largest one atop the hill. Can't miss it. Off with you now! Do what you must! Chop chop!" Barga prodded William along with his cane in the direction of the hill on the North end of The Garden.
